title: Started learning web basics
body: Began experimenting with HTML, CSS, and JavaScript through YouTube tutorials, setting up simple static websites.

title: First major project: High School Club Website
body: Built a club website using HTML, CSS, and JavaScript, with Firebase as a backend—my first time connecting a frontend to a database.

title: Pandemic learning sprint
body: Refined my JavaScript skills and rebuilt the club website from scratch, learning the importance of iteration and continuous improvement.

title: First steps into backend development
body: Dove into Node.js and Express, realizing how APIs link frontends to real-world data and broadening my scope beyond frontend-only projects.

title: Started Computer Science at UD
body: Accepted into University of Delaware as a CS major. Gained first exposure to formal CS theory and low-level programming, which challenged me but expanded my foundations.

title: Learning React.js
body: Explored component-based development. At first, concepts like state, props, and hooks were confusing, but once they clicked, I understood how modern apps scale.

title: Exploring the full stack
body: Started combining MongoDB, Express, React, and Node.js into small applications. This marked the beginning of my full-stack development journey.

title: First hackathon (lost, but learned)
body: Participated in UD's hackathon. My team didn’t win, but I learned to brainstorm quickly, work under pressure, and appreciate the creativity of other teams.

title: Campus jobs
body: Became a TA for the UD computer science department and worked tech support for the business college, strengthening my communication and problem-solving skills.

title: Adopted TypeScript
body: Transitioned my projects to TypeScript, focusing on type safety, maintainability, and scalability in web applications.

title: Shifted to TailwindCSS
body: Moved from vanilla CSS to TailwindCSS, learning how better tooling accelerates development and ensures design consistency.

title: First full-stack MERN deployment
body: Built and deployed an anonymous note-posting website on Vercel—my first live MERN project.

title: Shift toward independence
body: After not being rehired as a TA, I redirected my focus to personal projects and industry preparation, sharpening my self-driven learning habits.

title: Capstone and internship applications
body: Began my senior capstone project and applied to internships, targeting full-stack web development roles and practical industry experience.
